<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 278, 170, 293]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 297, 381, 313]]<|/det|>
Paper 4 A Level Structured Questions  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 339, 415, 355]]<|/det|>
Candidates answer on the Question Paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 359, 366, 375]]<|/det|>
No Additional Materials are required.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 390, 386, 408]]<|/det|>
## READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 416, 718, 490]]<|/det|>
Write your Centre number, candidate number and name on all the work you hand in. Write in dark blue or black pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs. Do not use staples, paper clips, glue or correction fluid. DO NOT WRITE IN ANY BARCODES.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 500, 255, 516]]<|/det|>
Answer all questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 526, 765, 558]]<|/det|>
Electronic calculators may be used. You may lose marks if you do not show your working or if you do not use appropriate units.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 567, 760, 598]]<|/det|>
At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together. The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question.

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 73, 124, 88]]<|/det|>
## Data  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 103, 670, 560]]<|/det|>
speed of light in free space \(c = 3.00\times 10^{8}\mathrm{m s}^{- 1}\) permeability of free space \(\mu_{0} = 4\pi \times 10^{- 7}\mathrm{Hm}^{- 1}\) permittivity of free space \(\epsilon_{0} = 8.85\times 10^{- 12}\mathrm{Fm}^{- 1}\) \((\frac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_{0}} = 8.99\times 10^{9}\mathrm{mF}^{- 1})\) elementary charge \(e = 1.60\times 10^{- 19}\mathrm{C}\) the Planck constant \(h = 6.63\times 10^{- 34}\mathrm{Js}\) unified atomic mass unit \(1u = 1.66\times 10^{- 27}\mathrm{kg}\) rest mass of electron \(m_{\mathrm{e}} = 9.11\times 10^{- 31}\mathrm{kg}\) rest mass of proton \(m_{\mathrm{p}} = 1.67\times 10^{- 27}\mathrm{kg}\) molar gas constant \(R = 8.31\mathrm{JK}^{- 1}\mathrm{mol}^{- 1}\) the Avogadro constant \(N_{\mathrm{A}} = 6.02\times 10^{23}\mathrm{mol}^{- 1}\) the Boltzmann constant \(k = 1.38\times 10^{- 23}\mathrm{JK}^{- 1}\) gravitational constant \(G = 6.67\times 10^{- 11}\mathrm{Nm}^{2}\mathrm{kg}^{- 2}\) acceleration of free fall \(g = 9.81\mathrm{m s}^{- 2}\)

\[f_0 = \frac{f_s\nu}{v\pm\nu_s}\]

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[444, 500, 593, 520]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[428, 637, 623, 656]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[295, 72, 700, 89]]<|/det|>
Answer **all** the questions in the spaces provided.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 103, 96, 121]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 103, 144, 121]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 102, 433, 121]]<|/det|>
State Newton's law of gravitation.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 225, 143, 243]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 225, 920, 259]]<|/det|>
The planet Jupiter and one of its moons, Io, may be considered to be uniform spheres that are isolated in space.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 257, 500, 275]]<|/det|>
Jupiter has radius \(R\) and mean density \(\rho\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 272, 920, 291]]<|/det|>
Io has mass \(m\) and is in a circular orbit about Jupiter with radius \(nR\), as illustrated in Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[256, 298, 737, 526]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 540, 532, 559]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 572, 583, 590]]<|/det|>
The time for Io to complete one orbit of Jupiter is \(T\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 603, 824, 622]]<|/det|>
Show that the time \(T\) is related to the mean density \(\rho\) of Jupiter by the expression

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[443, 626, 555, 655]]<|/det|>
\[\rho T^2 = \frac{3\pi n^3}{G}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 664, 463, 682]]<|/det|>
where \(G\) is the gravitational constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 917, 920, 935]]<|/det|>

<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 102, 556, 121]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 134, 520, 152]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 287, 920, 322]]<|/det|>
A thin metal strip, clamped horizontally at one end, has a load of mass \(M\) attached to its free end, as shown in Fig. 3.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 333, 870, 477]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 497, 532, 516]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 529, 520, 548]]<|/det|>
The metal strip bends, as shown in Fig. 3.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 560, 920, 593]]<|/det|>
When the free end of the strip is displaced vertically and then released, the mass oscillates in a vertical plane.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 591, 920, 625]]<|/det|>
Theory predicts that the variation of the acceleration \(a\) of the oscillating load with the displacement \(x\) from its equilibrium position is given by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[435, 632, 566, 662]]<|/det|>
\[a = -\left(\frac{c}{ML^3}\right)x\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 668, 777, 686]]<|/det|>
where \(L\) is the effective length of the metal strip and \(c\) is a positive constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 700, 181, 718]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 700, 910, 718]]<|/det|>
